content: This article contains a **list of Singaporean patriotic songs**. A patriotic song is one which inspires feelings of pride in one's country, which in this context is [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). The list has both traditional [folk songs](/wiki/Folk_music) that have special meaning to [Singaporeans](/wiki/Singaporeans), as well as modern songs composed specifically for national celebrations, particularly the [National Day Parade](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade) held on 9 August each year since 1965 on Singapore's [National Day](/wiki/National_Day_(Singapore)). Generally speaking, there may be said to be two types of [Singaporean](/wiki/Singaporeans) patriotic songs. The first type is traditional [folk songs](/wiki/Folk_music) that have, over time, come to have special meaning to [Singaporeans](/wiki/Singaporeans). Many of these are in [mother tongue](/wiki/Language_education_in_Singapore#Mother_Tongue) languages – [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language), [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language) and [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language), for instance. Examples of such songs include [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language) song "Xiao Ren Wu De Xin Sheng" "(小人物的心声)", [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language) song "Di Tanjung Katong" and [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language) song "Munnaeru Vaalibaa". The second type is the comparatively modern songs, mostly in [English](/wiki/English_language), that were composed specifically for national events – particularly the [National Day Parade](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade) held annually on 9 August – and for use in schools. Each year since 1985, the National Day Parade Executive Committee has designated one such song as a [National Day Parade theme song](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade#Theme_songs). The song is usually broadcast on radio and television starting from a month before National Day, and is given prominence during the Parade itself. Examples of such songs include "Stand Up for Singapore" (1985), "[Count On Me Singapore](/wiki/Count_On_Me_Singapore)" (1986) and "One People, One Nation, One Singapore" (1990). In 1998, there were two National Day Parade theme songs, "[Home](/wiki/Home_(Kit_Chan_song))" and "City For The World". The former was reused for the 2004 ceremony. In 2007, they used two National Day Parade theme songs, "There's No Place I'd Rather Be" and "Will You?". As for the National Day Ceremony song, "My People My Home", it was conducted by Dr [Lee Tzu Pheng](/wiki/Lee_Tzu_Pheng), it came out in the late 1990s and was reused for National Day Parade 2012, together with "[Love at First Light](/wiki/Love_at_First_Light)" which is sung by singer [Olivia Ong](/wiki/Olivia_Ong). In 1984, the [National Arts Council](/wiki/National_Arts_Council_Singapore) inaugurated the Sing Singapore Festival, with the aim of discovering and promoting home-grown music and artistes. According to the Council, it also hoped to nurture a love for music and singing and cultivate a greater sense of togetherness amongst Singaporeans. The programme led to the creation of a number of new songs by Singaporean composers, some of which were selected for National Day celebrations. These included "Home" (1998) by [Dick Lee](/wiki/Dick_Lee), "Where I Belong" (2001) by [Tanya Chua](/wiki/Tanya_Chua), and "A Place in My Heart" (2003) by Kevin Quah. Local singers such as [Taufik Batisah](/wiki/Taufik_Batisah), [Kit Chan](/wiki/Kit_Chan) and [Stefanie Sun](/wiki/Stefanie_Sun) have performed songs in the Sing Singapore collection. ## The National Songs highlighted in yellow were designated as "community songs" by the National Arts Council. ## Reception A minor controversy also erupted over "There's No Place I'd Rather Be" (2007). Some people queried why the song does not mention Singapore by name, while others commented that the song was "touching" and that they related to it immediately, and that "[t]he spirit of patriotism is woven so well in the song". One correspondent to the *[Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times)* asked: "How did such a dreadful song become the National Day song?", lambasting the melody as "uninspiring" and the lyrics as "insipid" – "it is quite obvious what the brief to [the composer] was: Write a song to persuade Singaporeans who have sought greener pastures to come home." The song's composer Jimmy Ye defended it, saying, "There's no need for it to be so in-your-face just because it's a National Day song". He noted that he had submitted the first draft of the song to the National Day Parade song committee, which had returned it with several changes. There was no mention of why "Singapore" got left out: "I guess the committee wanted to have a soft-sell approach too". Apart from "There's No Place I'd Rather Be", earlier songs like "Shine On Me" (2000), "Where I Belong" (2001), and "We Will Get There" (2002) also do not mention Singapore by name. - [Music of Singapore – National Day songs](/wiki/Music_of_Singapore#National_Day_songs) - [National Day Parade – Theme songs](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade#Theme_songs) ## Notes - Aisha Akbar, comp.
